channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: 4 Israeli soldiers killed in Hezbollah drone attack that leaves dozens injured
item.description: The Lebanese militant group targeted an Israeli army base near the central city of Binyamina, in one of the most serious mass casualty attacks the Iran-backed Lebanese militant group has caused in Israel.
item.content:encoded:
The Lebanese militant group targeted an Israeli army base near the central city of Binyamina, in one of the most serious mass casualty attacks the Iran-backed Lebanese militant group has caused in Israel.

(Image credit: Amir Levy)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Man with guns arrested near Trump rally in Coachella, sheriff says
item.description: Shotgun, handgun and magazines were found in car of man arrested on Saturday, according to authorities
item.content:encoded:
Shotgun, handgun and magazines were found in car of man arrested on Saturday, according to authorities

(Image credit: Alex Brandon/AP)
item.dc:creator: Luke Garrett

item.title: Deep inside a Norwegian fjord, a dream of farming salmon sustainably
item.description:
If you eat salmon, there's a good chance that it comes from a salmon farm in Norway. The country has been farming salmon for over 50 years.

The industry is touted as a key producer of sustainable, low carbon footprint protein. But there are still negative environmental impacts. Each year, an average of 200,000 farmed salmon escape from their open net pens and breed with wild salmon.

Interbreeding with these escaped salmon passes on significant genetic changes to wild salmon, changes that make them less likely to survive in the wild.

NPR's Rob Schmitz traveled the country's west coast, visiting fishing villages and fish farms to see how the growth of salmon farming is affecting the wild population.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
If you eat salmon, there's a good chance that it comes from a salmon farm in Norway. The country has been farming salmon for over 50 years.

The industry is touted as a key producer of sustainable, low carbon footprint protein. But there are still negative environmental impacts. Each year, an average of 200,000 farmed salmon escape from their open net pens and breed with wild salmon.

Interbreeding with these escaped salmon passes on significant genetic changes to wild salmon, changes that make them less likely to survive in the wild.

NPR's Rob Schmitz traveled the country's west coast, visiting fishing villages and fish farms to see how the growth of salmon farming is affecting the wild population.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Natalie Maynor)

item.title: Ruth Chepngetich breaks women's world record by almost 2 minutes at Chicago Marathon
item.description: The 30-year-old Kenyan became the first woman to break a marathon time of 2 hours 10 minutes, and cut almost 2 minutes off the previous women's record.
item.content:encoded:
The 30-year-old Kenyan became the first woman to break a marathon time of 2 hours 10 minutes, and cut almost 2 minutes off the previous women's record.

(Image credit: Michael Reaves)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Biden surveys Milton damage in Florida and announces funding for electric grid
item.description: President Biden touched down in St. Pete Beach, on one of Florida's barrier islands hit hard by the storm. He announced more than $600 million for shoring up parts of the nation's electric grid.
item.content:encoded:
President Biden touched down in St. Pete Beach, on one of Florida's barrier islands hit hard by the storm. He announced more than $600 million for shoring up parts of the nation's electric grid.

(Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: How one Afro-Colombian community honors their ancestry
item.description: In the town of Juntas, in the city of Buenaventura, Colombia, the community gathers for Holy Week every year to celebrate the Manacillos festival, an ancestral ritual originating in the upper part of the Yurumangui River.
item.content:encoded:
In the town of Juntas, in the city of Buenaventura, Colombia, the community gathers for Holy Week every year to celebrate the Manacillos festival, an ancestral ritual originating in the upper part of the Yurumangui River.

(Image credit: Nathalia Angarita for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Nathalia Angarita

item.title: U.S. to send air defense system and troops to Israel
item.description: The Pentagon said it will deploy the Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense battery and crew to Israel after recent Iranian missile attacks.
item.content:encoded:
The Pentagon said it will deploy the Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense battery and crew to Israel after recent Iranian missile attacks.

(Image credit: Ariel Schalit)
item.dc:creator: Luke Garrett

item.title: SpaceX rocket booster successfully 'caught' on first attempt during flight test
item.description: SpaceX conducted its fifth flight test of Starship, its most powerful spacecraft.
item.content:encoded:
SpaceX conducted its fifth flight test of Starship, its most powerful spacecraft.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: Deep inside a Norwegian fjord, a dream of farming salmon sustainably
item.description: In Norway, one man's solution to the threat posed by farmed salmon and the impact on the fjords they swim in.
item.content:encoded:
In Norway, one man's solution to the threat posed by farmed salmon and the impact on the fjords they swim in.

(Image credit: Rob Schmitz)
item.dc:creator: Rob Schmitz

item.title: Inside the TikTok documents: Stripping teens and boosting 'attractive' people
item.description: A trove of secret documents show teens’ increasing reliance on TikTok and how executives were acutely aware of the potential harm the app can cause young people, but appeared unconcerned.
item.content:encoded:
A trove of secret documents show teens’ increasing reliance on TikTok and how executives were acutely aware of the potential harm the app can cause young people, but appeared unconcerned.

(Image credit: Damian Dovarganes)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn
